_prev_prog_2.FR_OtherType: Applicable building, electrical and plumbing codes. This facility complies with the Iowa Fertilizer Law.
_prev_prog_2.FR_Comments: We utilize those portions of these codes which are deemed applicable by the jurisdictional authority
_prev_prog_2.MH_OtherType: Vandalism/theft; vehicular protection; potential leaking from underground piping
_prev_prog_2.PC_OtherType: Breakaway couplers at the risers and remote emergency shut-off valves at the storage tanks
_prev_prog_2.MS_OtherType: Regular plant inspection / Routine preventive maintenance & repair
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Pumps, pump seals, pipes and plumbing, valves, electrical and safety equipment. The breakaway couplers, pressure relief valves and hoses are also inspected and replaced as necessary.

_accidents.CF_Other: Damage caused by extended applicator boom
_accidents.CI_OtherType: Reminder to applicator employees to retract booms prior to traveling through facility

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION/EMERGENCY RESPONSE 

This facility complies with ANSI/CGA G-2.1-2014 requirements with amendments for Anhydrous Ammonia storage.  It is our policy to adhere to all applicable Federal, State, and local regulations.  If an emergency were to occur, it is our policy to immediately notify the local fire department (via a 911 call) and request that it respond to the emergency. Incidental to the fire department notification, the appropriate LEPC/EMA will be contacted.

While we have planned for an emergency, it is acknowledged that a real emergency will be unexpected and may be much different and cannot be ensured to duplicate what may have been planned. In reality, the situation that develops may not happen in the manner in which it has been planned.  In that event, what may have been planned will serve only as a guideline to follow.  

The Emergency Action Plan for this facility describes certain procedures that are intended to minimize the hazards associated with human health and the environment from fires, explosions, the sudden and unexpected release of chemicals (i.e., Anhydrous Ammonia), tornadoes, bomb threats or other accidents or Acts of God which might occur on our premises.  The primary emergency coordinator for the facility is the location manager. 


DESCRIPTION OF THE ANHYDROUS AMMONIA STORAGE/DISTRIBUTION PLANT AND THE REGULATED SUBSTANCE HANDLED AT THE FACILITY

This facility is a bulk anhydrous ammonia storage and distribution plant.  The anhydrous ammonia, stored at this facility, is distributed to agricultural crop producers in the surrounding area who utilize anhydrous ammonia for crop nutrient purposes. The system consists of storage vessel(s) with associated piping, valves, liquid pump(s), and other miscellaneous equipment.  From time-to-time throughout the year, portable nurse tanks may also be present at this site. The anhydrous ammonia plant is operated on a seasonal basis (Spring and Fall).  Full-time equi

valent employee numbers were computed on that basis. The plant operates a total of three months (1/4 of the year).  The FTEs for the facility is three (3).


GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

This facility complies with EPA's accident prevention rule and all applicable State and local codes and regulations. The anhydrous ammonia system is designed, installed, and maintained in accordance with ANSI/CGA G-2.1-2014 with amendments and State law.

In addition, the company has specific operating procedures in place intended to minimize the potential for an accidental (and potentially catastrophic) release of anhydrous ammonia.  The company has extended to the responding fire department the opportunity to visit our anhydrous ammonia plant, to participate in mock emergency simulation training, and to avail themselves of specific anhydrous ammonia health hazard information and training provided by the company. 


FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

This facility experienced an uncontrolled release from a 30,000 storage vessel on April 16, 2019 at/or around 9:26 AM.  The release was caused by an applicator machine that had the applicator boom extended while an employee was travelling through the facility property.  The boom struck the pop off valve and the vessel began releasing NH3. Emergency (911) was contacted and responded.  HazMat response was also onsite. The road (245th Street) adjacent to the facility was closed by local law enforcement due to the wind blowing the release across the road.  Adjacent businesses and businesses across 245th Street were evacuated as a precaution.  Approximately 35 to 40 persons were evacuated, plus 7 employees.  No other evacuation was required.  No injures occurred.  No sheltering occurred. No deaths occurred. No product reached waters of the State.  

Due to the loss of the pop-off valve, response teams determined that there was no safe way to stop the release.  Somewhere at/or a

round 1:40 PM, the noise from the release appeared to stop.  HazMat teams investigated and found that the product stored in the vessel had frozen causing the release to stop.  HazMat teams developed and implemented a plan to replace the pop-off valve to permanently stop the release.  This was completed on/or about 2:40 PM.  HazMat teams called an "ALL CLEAR" at this time.  Buildings on and surrounding the facility were checked for gas smell prior to allowing persons into building.  No ammonia smell was found.  Incident Investigation began at /or around 3:30 PM. 


THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

In the event of an emergency involving our anhydrous ammonia system, it is the policy of the company  to immediately notify the responding fire department, and the appropriate LEPC/EMA to request that they respond to the emergency.  In the unlikely event that the responding fire department is unable to adequately respond to an emergency at the location, the fire department with whom the responding fire department has a reciprocal agreement will be summoned.   This policy has been reviewed with the fire department and LEPC/EMA. 


PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The plan is to minimize those hazards to human health and to the environment that are associated with accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  Employees working at the bulk storage plant make routine observations prior to and during transfer operations of the anhydrous ammonia from the storage vessel(s) to nurse tanks.  In so doing, they are able to detect problems before they arise.  This routine inspection identifies any portion of the system which may be under stress or about to fail. Repairs can be made before they become problematic.  Employees are annually trained to recognize the hazards associated with storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia.  In addition to annual training for employees who have been on the job for a number of years, the company conducts training for new hires.  This training

includes classroom instruction, on-site training at the plant, and follow-up observation to determine their individual comprehension and understanding of the new hire.  The company routinely invites local fire department personnel to visit the site.  Should the local fire department request assistance in the training of its employees on the properties and characteristics of anhydrous ammonia, the company cooperates in their endeavors.
